PANG.d: A paroxysm of extreme physical pain or anguish; a feeling of sudden and transitory agony; a throe.
PANG.e: The origin of the noun is uncertain; it is possibly derived from Middle English *pange, perhaps an altered form of prange, prōnge (“affliction, agony, pain; pointed instrument”) as in prongys of deth (“pangs of death, death throes”), from Anglo-Latin pronga, of unknown origin. Pe...

PANS.d: Plural of PAN: Greek god of nature, often visualized as half goat and half man playing pipes. His Roman counterpart is Faunus.
PANS.e: From Middle English Pan, from Latin Pān, from Ancient Greek Πάν (Pán).

PANT.d: A quick breathing; a catching of the breath; a gasp: the panting of animals such as a dog with their tong hung out- as a form of thermoregulation.
PANT.e:
From Middle English panten, whence also English dialectal pank.
Possibly from Old French pantoyer, a byform or of Old French pantoisier (“to be breathless”) (compare modern French panteler (“to gasp for breath”)), of uncertain origin. Possibly from Vulgar Latin *pantasiō (“strugg...

PAPA.d: Dad, daddy, father; a familiar or old-fashioned term of address to one’s father.
PAPA.e: From French papa, from Middle French papa, from Old French papa, from Latin papa, probably originally a reduplicated imitation of a child's early efforts at vocalising Latin pater (“father”). Compare Ancient Greek πάππας (páppas, “papa, daddy”).

PAPS.d: Plural of PAP: Food in the form of a soft paste, often a porridge, especially as given to very young children.
PAPS.e: From Middle English pap. Related to Middle Low German pappe, Dutch pap, German Pappe (“pap, porridge; wheatpaste; cardboard”), Old French papa/pape, Latin pappa, Bulgarian папам (papam, “to eat”) and Serbo-Croatian папати/papati (“to eat”), among others. The relationships between...

PARA.d: A former subunit of currency in several countries in the Ottoman/Turkish and Yugoslav regions.
PARA.e: Borrowed from Serbo-Croatian pàra /па̀ра, from Ottoman Turkish پاره (pare, para), from Persian پاره (pâre).

PARE.d: To remove the outer covering or skin of something with a cutting device, typically a knife.
PARE.e: From Middle English paren, from Old French parer (“to arrange, prepare, trim”), from Latin parō (“I prepare, arrange; I provide, furnish; I resolve, purpose”) (related to pariō (“I bear, I give birth to; I spawn, produce, beget; I procure, acquire”)), from a Proto-Indo-European *...

PARK.d: An area of land set aside for environment preservation or recreation.
PARK.e: From Middle English park, from Old French parc (“livestock pen”), from Medieval Latin parcus, parricus, from Frankish *parrik (“enclosure, pen, fence”). Cognate with Dutch perk (“enclosure; flowerbed”), Old High German pfarrih, pferrih (“enclosure, pen”), Old English pearroc (“en...

PART.e: From Middle English part, from Old English part (“part”) and Old French part (“part”); both from Latin partem, accusative of pars (“piece, portion, share, side, party, faction, role, character, lot, fate, task, lesson, part, member”), from Proto-Indo-European *par-, *per- (“to se...

PASH.d: To snog, to make out, to kiss.

PASS.e: From Middle English passen, from Old French passer (“to step, walk, pass”), from Vulgar Latin *passāre (“step, walk, pass”), derived from Latin passus (“a step”), from Proto-Italic *pat-s-tus, from Proto-Indo-European *peth₂- (“to spread, stretch out”). Cognate with Old English f...

PAST.d: The period of time that has already happened, in contrast to the present and the future.
PAST.e: From Middle English passed, past participle of passen (“to pass, to go by”), whence Modern English pass.

PATE.d: The head, particularly the top or crown.
PATE.e: From Middle English pate, of uncertain origin. Perhaps a shortened form of Old French patene or Medieval Latin patena, both from Latin patina (“pan, dish”). Alternatively, perhaps akin to Old Frisian pote (“skull”).

PATH.d: A trail for the use of, or worn by, pedestrians.
PATH.e: From Middle English path, peth, from Old English pæþ (“path, track”), from Proto-West Germanic *paþ, from Proto-Germanic *paþaz (“path”). The Proto-Germanic term is possibly borrowed from Iranian, from Proto-Iranian *pántaHh, from Proto-Indo-Iranian *pántaHs, from Proto-Indo-Euro...

PATS.d: Plural of PAT: The sound of a light slap or tap with a soft flat object, especially of a footstep.
PATS.e: From Middle English *patten, alteration (with loss of medial l) of platten, pletten (“to pat”), from Old English plættan (“to buffet, strike, slap, smack, give a sounding blow”), from Proto-Germanic *plat- (“to strike, beat”), from Proto-Indo-European *blod-, *bled- (“to strike, ...

PAUA.d: Any of several large, edible abalones of New Zealand, especially Haliotis iris, whose shell is used to make jewelry.

PAVE.d: To cover something with paving slabs.
PAVE.e: From Old French paver (“to pave, to cover”), from Vulgar Latin *pavāre (“to beat down, to smash”), from Latin pavīre (“to beat, strike, ram, tread down”).

PAWL.d: A pivoted catch designed to fall into a notch on a ratchet wheel so as to allow movement in only one direction (e.g. on a windlass or in a clock mechanism), or alternatively to move the wheel in one direction.
PAWL.e: 17th c., perhaps from Low German or Dutch pal (“catch (mechanism)”), or from either French pal (“stake”) or épaule (“shoulder”).

PAWN.d: The state of being held as security for a loan, or as a pledge.
PAWN.e: From Middle English paun, pawyn, pawnd, from Old French pan, pant (“pledge for a payment”), from a Germanic language, perhaps Frankish *pand (“deposit, security, pledge”), further origin uncertain. Cognate with Saterland Frisian Pound (“deposit, pledge, pawn”), West Frisian pân (...

PAWS.d: Plural of PAW: The soft foot of a mammal or other animal, generally a quadruped, that has claws or nails; comparable to a human hand or foot.
PAWS.e: From Middle English pawe, from Old French poue, poe, from Frankish *pōta (compare Dutch poot, Low German Pote, German Pfote), from Frankish *pōtōn (“to put, stick, plant”) (compare Dutch poten (“to plant”)), from Proto-Germanic *putōną (compare Old English potian (“to push”), pȳt...

PAYS.d: third-person singular simple present indicative of pay

PEAK.d: A point; the sharp end or top of anything that terminates in a point; as, the peak, or front, of a cap.
PEAK.e:
From earlier peake, peek, peke, from Middle English pek (in place names), itself an alteration of pike, pyke, pyk (“a sharp point, pike”), from Old English pīc, piic (“a pike, needle, pin, peak, pinnacle”), from Proto-West Germanic *pīk, from Proto-Germanic *pīkaz (“peak”).
Cogna...

PEAL.d: A loud sound, or a succession of loud sounds, as of bells, thunder, cannon, shouts, laughter, of a multitude, etc.
PEAL.e: From Middle English pele, peil, probably an apheretic variant of Middle English apel, appel, from Old French apel (“an appeal; pealing of bells”). Compare appeal.

PEAN.d: A heraldic fur of gold spots on a black field.
PEAN.e: Derived from Middle French penne (“feather”), from penna (“feather”); doublet of pen and penna.

PEAR.d: An edible fruit produced by the pear tree, similar to an apple but typically elongated towards the stem.
PEAR.e:
From Middle English pere, from Old English pere, from Proto-West Germanic *peru, from Vulgar Latin pira, originally the plural of Latin pirum but reconstrued as a feminine singular, ultimately a loanword from an unknown Mediterranean substrate source.
Cognate with Scots peer (“pe...

PEAS.d: Plural of PEA: Any of certain plants of the family Fabaceae: Pisum sativum and others.
PEAS.e: Back-formation from pease, an original singular reinterpreted as a plural. Further from Middle English pese (“a pea”), from Old English pise, from Latin pisa, pisum, from Ancient Greek πίσον (píson).

PEAT.d: Soil formed of dead but not fully decayed plants found in bog areas, often burned as fuel.
PEAT.e: Inherited from Northern Middle English pete (recorded in Latin text as peta), of uncertain origin; perhaps from a Celtic language such as an unattested Pictish or Brythonic source, in turn possibly from Proto-Brythonic *peθ (“portion, segment, piece”); if so, it would be a double...

PECK.d: To strike or pierce with the beak or bill (of a bird).
PECK.e: From Middle English pecken, pekken, variant of Middle English piken, picken, pikken (“to pick, use a pointed implement”). More at pick.

PEEK.d: To look slyly, or with the eyes half closed, or through a crevice; to peep.
PEEK.e: From Middle English *peken, piken, pyken (“to peep”), probably a fusion of Middle English pepen (“to peep”) and keken, kiken (“to keek, look, spy”), equivalent to a blend of peep + keek. Perhaps also possibly a metathetic alteration of Middle English kepen, kipen, kypen (“to keep...

PEEL.d: To remove the skin or outer covering of.
PEEL.e: From Middle English pelen, from Old English pilian and Old French peler, pellier; both from Latin pilō, pilāre (“to remove hair from, depilate”), from pilus (“hair”). Doublet of pill.

PEEN.d: The (often spherical) end of the head of a hammer opposite the main hammering end.
PEEN.e: Probably from a North Germanic source, compare dialectal Norwegian penn (“peen”), Danish pind (“peg”), German Pinne (“the peen of a hammer”), Old Swedish pæna (“to pound iron with a hammer”).

PEEP.d: A short, soft, high-pitched sound, as made by a baby bird.
PEEP.e: From Middle English pepen. Compare Dutch piepen (“peep”), German Low German piepen (“to peep”), German piepen and pfeifen, all probably onomatopoeic.

PEER.d: To look with difficulty, or as if searching for something.
PEER.e: From Middle English peren, pyren, piren (“to peer, gaze”), perhaps from Old English *pȳran (“to look, peer”), from Proto-West Germanic *pūrijan (“to look”), related to Saterland Frisian pierje (“to look”), Dutch Low Saxon piren (“to look”), West Flemish pieren (“to look with narr...

PEES.e: The initial letter of piss. Compare eff.

PEGS.d: Plural of PEG: A cylindrical wooden or metal object used to fasten or as a bearing between objects.
PEGS.e: From Middle English pegge, from Middle Dutch pegge (“pin, peg”), from Old Dutch *pigg-, *pegg-, from Proto-Germanic *pig-, *pag- (“peg, stake”), from Proto-Indo-European *bak-, *baḱ- (“club, pointed stick, peg”). Cognate with Dutch dialectal peg (“pin”), Low German pig, pigge (“p...

PELE.d: The Hawaiian goddess of fire and volcanos.

PELF.d: Money, riches; gain, especially when dishonestly acquired; lucre, mammon.
PELF.e: From Late Middle English pelf, pelfe (“stolen goods, booty, spoil; forfeited property; money, riches; property; valuable object”), possibly from Anglo-Norman pelf (a variant of pelfre (“booty, loot”)) and Old French peufre (“frippery; rubbish”); further etymology uncertain, possi...

PELL.e: From Latin pellis (“animal skin, pelt”), from Proto-Italic *pelnis, from Proto-Indo-European *pel-ni-. Distantly related to fell and film.

PELT.d: The skin of an animal with the hair or wool on; either a raw or undressed hide, or a skin preserved with the hair or wool on it (sometimes worn as a garment with minimal modification).
PELT.e:
The noun is inherited from Middle English pelt (“skin of a sheep, especially without the wool”); further etymology uncertain, possibly:
* from Middle English pellet (“skin of an animal, especially a sheep”), from Anglo-Norman pelette, pellet, and Old French pelete, pelette (“thin...

PEND.d: To hang down; to cause something to hang down
PEND.e: Borrowed from Middle French pendre (“to hang”), from Late Latin pendĕre, from Latin pendēre.

PEON.d: A lowly person; a peasant or serf; a labourer who is obliged to do menial work.
PEON.e: From a combination of Middle French pion, peon and Spanish peón, both from Late Latin pedōnem (“pedestrian”). Doublet of pawn.

PEPO.d: A fruit of plants of the gourd family Cucurbitaceae, possessing a hard rind and producing many seeds in a single, central, pulpy chamber.
PEPO.e: Borrowed from Latin pepō, from Ancient Greek πέπων (pépōn, “large melon”), from πέπων (pépōn, “ripe”), from πέπτω (péptō, “ripen”). Doublet of pumpion; compare pumpkin.

PEPS.d: Plural of PEP: To inject with energy and enthusiasm.

PERI.e: Borrowed from Ottoman Turkish پری (peri), from Persian پری (pari).

PERS.e: From Latin per (“through, during”), from Proto-Indo-European *per. Doublet of par.

PERT.e: From Middle English pert, perte, aphetic form of apert.

PESO.d: A former unit of currency in Spain and Spain's colonies, worth 8 reales; the Spanish dollar.

PEST.d: A pestilence, i.e. a deadly epidemic, a deadly plague.
PEST.e: In the 16th century in the sense of "pestilence" and specifically bubonic plague from Middle French peste (“pestilence”) (whence French peste). The other meanings are recorded soon after. Ultimately from Latin pestis.

PETS.d: Plural of PET: An animal kept as a companion or otherwise for pleasure, rather than for some practical benefit or use.
PETS.e: Originally northern dialectal, from Scots pet (“an animal that has been tamed and is kept as a pet; a darling or favourite; a petted or spoiled child”), probably from Scottish Gaelic peata (“pet, tamed animal, spoiled child”), from Middle Irish petta, peta (“pet, lap-dog”), of un...

PEWS.d: Plural of PEW: One of the long benches in a church, seating several persons, usually fixed to the floor and facing the chancel.
PEWS.e: From Middle English pewe, from Old French puiee, puïe (“balustrade, balcony”), from Latin podia, plural of podium (“parapet, podium”), from Ancient Greek πόδιον (pódion, “little foot”), from πούς (poús, “foot”). Doublet of podia.

PHEW.d: Used to express relief of tension, fatigue, or surprise.
PHEW.e: Attested since the early 17th century. An onomatopoeia for rapid exhalation, as one may make when a trying situation is over, or in order to get rid of an unpleasant odour. Compare Scots feuch, Spanish fu, Czech fuj, and many more such forms.

PHIS.d: Plural of PHI: Φ, the 21st letter of the Euclidean and modern Greek alphabet, usually romanized as "ph".
PHIS.e: From Late Latin phi, from Ancient Greek φεῖ (pheî).

PHON.d: A unit of apparent loudness, equal in number to the intensity in decibels of a 1,000-hertz tone judged to be as loud as the sound being measured.

PICA.d: A disorder characterized by appetite and craving for non-edible substances, such as chalk, clay, dirt, ice, or sand.
PICA.e:
Borrowed from Latin pīca (“jay; magpie”). Doublet of pie (“magpie”).
* (pathology): From the idea that magpies will eat almost anything.

PICK.d: A tool used for digging; a pickaxe.
PICK.e: From Middle English piken, picken, pikken, from Old English *piccian, *pīcian (attested in pīcung (“a pricking”)), and pīcan, pȳcan (“to pick, prick, pluck”), both from Proto-West Germanic *pikkōn, from Proto-Germanic *pikkōną (“to pick, peck, prick, knock”), from Proto-Indo-Euro...

PICS.d: Plural of PIC: A picture, especially a photographic image.

PIED.d: Past tense of PIE: A type of pastry that consists of an outer crust and a filling. (Savory pies are more popular in the UK and sweet pies are more popular in the US, so "pie" without qualification has different connotations in these dialects.)
PIED.e: From Middle English pye, pie, pey, perhaps from Old English *pīe (“pastry”) (compare Old English pīe, pēo (“insect, bug”)), attested in early Middle English piehus (“bakery”, literally “pie-house”) c. 1199. Relation to Medieval Latin pica, pia (“pie, pastry”) is unclear, as there...

PIES.d: Plural of PIE: A type of pastry that consists of an outer crust and a filling. (Savory pies are more popular in the UK and sweet pies are more popular in the US, so "pie" without qualification has different connotations in these dialects.)
PIES.e: From Middle English pye, pie, pey, perhaps from Old English *pīe (“pastry”) (compare Old English pīe, pēo (“insect, bug”)), attested in early Middle English piehus (“bakery”, literally “pie-house”) c. 1199. Relation to Medieval Latin pica, pia (“pie, pastry”) is unclear, as there...

PIGS.d: Plural of PIG: Any of several mammalian species of the family Suidae, having cloven hooves, bristles and a snout adapted for digging; especially the domesticated animal Sus domesticus.
PIGS.e: From Middle English pigge (“pig, pigling”) (originally a term for a young pig, with adult pigs being swyn (“swine”)), apparently from Old English *picga (attested only in compounds, such as picgbrēad (“mast, pig-fodder”)), from Proto-West Germanic *piggō, *puggō (“piglet”). Compa...

PIKE.d: A very long spear used two-handed by infantry soldiers for thrusting (not throwing), both for attacks on enemy foot soldiers and as a countermeasure against cavalry assaults.
PIKE.e: From Middle English pyke, pyk, pik, pike (“pike; sharp point, iron tip of a staff or spear, pointed toe of an item of footwear; sharp tool; mountain, peak”), from Old English pīc (“pointed object, pick axe”), and Middle French pique (“long thrusting weapon”), from Old French pic ...

PILE.d: A mass of things heaped together; a heap.
PILE.e: From Middle English pyle, from Old French pile, from Latin pīla (“pillar, pier”).

PILL.d: A small, usually round or cylindrical object designed for easy swallowing, usually containing some sort of medication.
PILL.e:
* From Middle English pille (also pillem), a borrowing from Middle Low German pille or Middle Dutch pille (whence Dutch pil), probably from Latin pila, pilula.
* (persuade or convince): Generalized from red pill.

PIMP.d: Someone who solicits customers for prostitution and acts as manager for a group of prostitutes; a pander.
PIMP.e: Origin unknown. Perhaps from French pimpant (“smart, sparkish”) or German Pimpf (“boy, youth, young squirt”). The Old English near-synonym was rendered by Old English forspennend (literally “solicitor”).

PINE.d: Any coniferous tree of the genus Pinus.
PINE.e: From Middle English pyne, from Old English *pīne, from Proto-West Germanic *pīnā, from Latin pīnus, see there for more. Doublet of pinus. Possibly related to fat.

PING.d: A high-pitched, short and somewhat sharp sound.
PING.e: Partly onomatopoeic, and partly continuing Middle English pingen (“to push, shove, pierce, stab, prod, goad, urge, feel remorse, incite”), from Old English pyngan (“to prick”), in turn likely from pungere. Compare English pang.

PINK.d: A color reminiscent of pinks, the flowers.
PINK.e: Origin uncertain; perhaps from Dutch pinken (“blink”) or the English verb pink from the same source. Perhaps from the notion of the petals being pinked.

PINT.d: A unit of volume, equivalent to:
PINT.e: From Middle English pinte, from Old French pinte, assumed from Vulgar Latin *pincta (“a mark used to indicate a level of quantity against a larger measure”), from Latin picta (“painted”), from Latin pingō (“paint”, verb). Doublet of pinto and Pinto.

PINY.d: Of, pertaining to, or having many pines.

PION.d: Any of three semistable mesons, having positive, negative or neutral charge, composed of up and down quarks/antiquarks.
PION.e: From pi + -on, as alteration of pi-meson.

PIPA.d: A pear-shaped plucked lute from China.
PIPA.e: From Mandarin 琵琶 (pípá). Doublet of bipa and biwa, and possibly barbat and barbitos.

PIPE.d: Meanings relating to a wind instrument.
PIPE.e: From Middle English pīpe, pype (“hollow cylinder or tube used as a conduit or container; duct or vessel of the body; musical instrument; financial records maintained by the English Exchequer, pipe roll”), from Old English pīpe (“pipe (musical instrument); the channel of a small s...

PIPS.d: Plural of PIP: Any of various respiratory diseases in birds, especially infectious coryza.
PIPS.e: From Middle English pippe, from Middle Dutch pip, from post-classical Latin pipita, from Latin pītuīta (“mucus, phlegm, head cold”). Doublet of pituita.

PIRK.d: A type of fishing lure consisting of a metal bar with a treble hook attached.

PISH.e: Expressive; perhaps partly from Scots pish (“piss”).

PISS.e: From Middle English pisse (noun) and pissen (verb), from Old French pissier, possibly from Vulgar Latin *pīssiāre, probably of imitative origin. Compare Old Norse pissa (“to urinate, piss”). Displaced Old English micge.

PITH.d: The soft, spongy substance inside plant parts; specifically, the parenchyma in the centre of the roots and stems of many plants and trees.
PITH.e: The noun is derived from Middle English pith, pithe (“central tissue of a plant’s stem or a tree’s trunk and branches; other spongy inner tissue in a plant; flesh of a fruit, pulp; inner tissue in a body; inner part of an object; essential part, essence, quintessence; importance,...

PITS.d: Plural of PIT: A hole in the ground.
PITS.e: From Middle English pit, pet, püt, from Old English pytt, from Proto-West Germanic *puti, from Latin puteus (“trench, pit, well”), although there are phonetic difficulties.

PITY.d: A feeling of sympathy at the misfortune or suffering of someone or something.
PITY.e: From Middle English pitye, pitie, pittye, pitee, pite, from Anglo-Norman pité, pittee etc., from Old French pitet, pitié, from Latin pietās. See also the doublets pietà and piety.

PLAN.d: A drawing showing technical details of a building, machine, etc., with unwanted details omitted, and often using symbols rather than detailed drawing to represent doors, valves, etc.
PLAN.e: From French plan (“flat surface, ground plot, map”), from Latin plānus. Some sources also argue for influence or alteration of French plant, from plantar, from Latin plantāre (“set, fix in place”). Compare plane, plain.

PLAT.d: A plot of land; a lot.
PLAT.e: The noun is derived from Middle English plat, platte (“flat part of a sword; flat piece of ground, plot of ground”), probably a variant of Middle English plot, (modern English plot) and influenced by Middle English plat, plate (modern English plate) and Anglo-Norman, Middle Frenc...

PLAY.d: To act in a manner such that one has fun; to engage in activities expressly for the purpose of recreation or entertainment.
PLAY.e: From Middle English pleyen, playen, pleȝen, plæien, also Middle English plaȝen, plawen (compare English plaw), from Old English pleġan, pleoġan, plæġan, and Old English plegian, pleagian, plagian (“to play, exercise, etc.”), from Proto-West Germanic *plehan (“to care about, be co...

PLEA.d: An appeal, petition, urgent prayer or entreaty.
PLEA.e: From Middle English ple, from Old French plait, plaid, from Medieval Latin placitum (“a decree, sentence, suit, plea, etc., Latin an opinion, determination, prescription, order; literally, that which is pleasing, pleasure”), neuter of placitus, past participle of placere (“to ple...

PLEB.d: A commoner; a member of the lower class of a society.
PLEB.e: A clipping of plebeian and plebe, sometimes also understood as a back-formation from plebs.

PLOD.d: A slow or labored walk or other motion or activity.
PLOD.e: From Middle English *plodden (found only in derivative plodder), probably originally a splash through water and mud, from plodde, pludde (“a puddle”) (whence modern plud). Compare Scots plod, plodge, plodder, dialectal Dutch plodden, plodderen, dialectal German ploddern, Danish p...

PLOP.d: A sound or action like liquid hitting a hard surface, or an object falling into a body of water.
PLOP.e: Imitative of the sound, or perhaps a variant of plap.

PLOT.d: The course of a story, comprising a series of incidents which are gradually unfolded, sometimes by unexpected means.
PLOT.e: From Middle English plot, plotte, from Old English plot (“a plot of ground”), from Proto-Germanic *plataz, *platjaz (“a patch”), of uncertain origin. Cognate with Middle Low German plet (“patch, strip of cloth, rags”), German Bletz (“rags, bits, strip of land”), and possibly Goth...

PLOY.e: Possibly from a shortened form of employ or deploy. Or from earlier ploye, from Middle English, borrowed from Middle French ployer (compare modern plier), from Latin plicāre.

PLUG.d: A pronged connecting device which fits into a mating socket, especially an electrical one.
PLUG.e: From Dutch plug, from Middle Dutch plugge (“peg, plug”), from Old Dutch *pluggi, from Proto-West Germanic *plugi. Further origin unknown. Possibly from Proto-Germanic *plugjaz, but the word seems originally restricted to northern continental West Germanic. Perhaps ultimately from...

PLUM.e: From Middle English plomme, ploume, from Old English plūme, from Proto-West Germanic *plūmā, borrowed from Latin prūnum. Doublet of prune.

PLUS.d: And; sum of the previous one and the following one.

POCK.d: A pus-filled swelling on the surface on the skin caused by an eruptive disease.
POCK.e: From Middle English pok, from Old English poc, pocc (“pock; pustule; ulcer”), from Proto-West Germanic *pokk, from Proto-Germanic *pukkaz, *pukkǭ (“pock; swelling”), from Proto-Indo-European *bew-, *bʰew- (“to grow; swell”). Cognate with Dutch pok (“pock”), Low German Pocke (“poc...

PODS.d: Plural of POD: A seed case for legumes (e.g. peas, beans, peppers); a seedpod.
PODS.e: Origin uncertain. Perhaps from Middle English *pod ("seed-pod, husk, shell, outer covering"; attested in pod-ware (“legume seed; seed grain”)), itself possibly from Old English pād (“an outer garment, covering, coat, cloak”), from Proto-West Germanic *paidu, from Proto-Germanic *...

POEM.d: A literary piece written in verse.
POEM.e: From Middle French poème, from Latin poēma, from Ancient Greek ποίημα (poíēma), from ποιέω (poiéō, “I make”). Displaced native Old English lēoþ.

POET.e: From Middle English poete, from Old French poete, from Latin poēta (“poet, author”), from Ancient Greek ποιητής (poiētḗs, “creator, maker, author, poet”), from ποιέω (poiéō, “to make, compose”). Displaced native Old English sċop. Doublet of piyyut.

POKE.d: To prod or jab with an object such as a finger or a stick.
POKE.e: From Middle English poken, perhaps from Middle Dutch poken or Middle Low German poken, both from Proto-West Germanic *pukōn or similar, which is itself of uncertain origin, but may be from an imitative Proto-Germanic root *puk-. Doublet of poach.

POKY.d: A gambling device based on the card game poker.
POKY.e: By shortening from poker machine (“gambling device”).

POLE.d: Originally, a stick; now specifically, a long and slender piece of metal or (especially) wood, used for various construction or support purposes.
POLE.e: From Middle English pole, pal, from Old English pāl (“a pole, stake, post; a kind of hoe or spade”), from Proto-West Germanic *pāl (“pole”), from Latin pālus (“stake, pale, prop, stay”), perhaps from Old Latin *paxlos, from Proto-Italic *pākslos, ultimately from Proto-Indo-Europe...

POLL.d: A survey of people, usually statistically analyzed to gauge wider public opinion.
POLL.e: From Middle English pol, polle ("scalp, pate"), from or cognate with Middle Dutch pol, pōle, polle (“top, summit; head”), from Proto-West Germanic *poll, from Proto-Germanic *pullaz (“round object, head, top”), from Proto-Indo-European *bolno-, *bōwl- (“orb, round object, bubble”...

POLO.d: A ball game where two teams of players on horseback use long-handled mallets to propel the ball along the ground and into their opponent's goal.
POLO.e: From Balti پولو (polo, “ball”). Cognate with Tibetan པོ་ལོ (po lo), ཕོ་ལོང (pho long), སྤོ་ལོ (spo lo, “ball”).

POMP.d: Show of magnificence; parade; display; power.
POMP.e:
The noun is derived from Middle English pomp, pompe, from Old French pompe, from Latin pompa (“pomp”), from Ancient Greek πομπή (pompḗ, “a sending, a solemn procession, pomp”), from πέμπω (pémpō, “I send”).
The verb is derived from Middle English pompen, from pomp, pompe (see abo...

POND.d: An inland body of standing water, either natural or man-made, that is smaller than a lake.
POND.e: From Middle English pond, ponde (“pond, pool”), probably from Old English *pond, *pand (attested in placenames), a variant of *pund (“enclosure”). Doublet of pound.

PONE.d: A writ in law used by the superior courts to remove cases from inferior courts.
PONE.e: Inherited from Middle English pone, from Anglo-Norman pone, from Late Latin pone, from Latin pōne, imperative of pōnere (“to place”).

PONS.d: A bridge-like tissue connecting two parts of an organ.
PONS.e: Borrowed from Latin pōns (“bridge”). Doublet of Pontus.

PONY.d: A small horse; specifically, any of several small breeds of horse under 14.2 hands at the withers.
PONY.e: 1659 from Scots powny, apparently from Middle French poulenet (“little foal”), ultimately from Late Latin pullanus (“young of an animal”), from pullus (cognate to English foal). Sense “small serving of alcohol” from 19th century, both for small sizes generally and for a quarter p...

POOF.d: Onomatopoeia indicating a small explosion with a cloud of smoke; as caused by a deflating object, or a magical disappearance.

POOL.d: A small and rather deep area of (usually) fresh water, as one supplied by a spring, or occurring in the course of a stream or river; a reservoir for water.
POOL.e:
From Middle English pool, pole, pol, from Old English pōl (“pool”), from Proto-West Germanic pōl, from Proto-Germanic *pōlaz (“pool, pond”), from Proto-Indo-European *bōlos (“bog, marsh”).
Cognate with Scots puil (“pool”), Saterland Frisian Pol (“pool”), West Frisian poel (“pool”...

POON.d: Any of several East Indian trees of the genus Calophyllum, yielding a light, hard wood used for masts, spars, etc.
POON.e: Compare Tamil புன்னை (puṉṉai), Malayalam പുന്ന (punna), names for Calophyllum inophyllum. Doublet of punnai.

POOP.d: To make a short blast on a horn.
POOP.e: Uncertain, possibly from Middle English poupen (“to make a gulping sound while drinking, blow on a horn, toot”). Compare Dutch poepen (“to defecate”), German Low German pupen (“to fart; break wind”). Also representing poo pronounced with the mouth snapped closed at the end.

POOR.d: With no or few possessions or money, particularly in relation to contemporaries who do have them.
POOR.e:
Inherited from Middle English povre, povere, from Old French (and Anglo-Norman) povre, poure, from Latin pauper, from Old Latin *pavo-pars (literally “getting little”), from Proto-Indo-European *peh₂w- (“few, small”). Doublet of pauper.
Displaced native arm, wantsome, Middle Engl...

POPE.d: An honorary title of the Roman Catholic bishop of Rome as father and head of his church, a sovereign of the Vatican city state.
POPE.e: From Middle English pope, popa, from Old English pāpa, from Vulgar Latin papa (title for priests and bishops, esp. and by 8th c. only the bishop of Rome), from early Byzantine Greek παπᾶς (papâs, title for priests and bishops, especially by 3rd c. the bishop of Alexandria), from ...

POPS.d: Plural of POP: A loud, sharp sound, as of a cork coming out of a bottle, especially when the contents are pressurized by fizziness.
POPS.e: From Middle English pop, poppe (“a blow; strike; buffet”) (> Middle English poppen (“to strike; thrust”, verb)), of onomatopoeic origin – used to describe the sound, or short, sharp actions. The physics sense is part of a facetious sequence "snap, crackle, pop", after the mascots...

PORE.d: A tiny opening in the skin.
PORE.e: From Middle English pore, from Old French pore, from Latin porus, from Ancient Greek πόρος (póros, “passage”). Displaced native English sweat hole from Middle English swet hole, which might have been a reformation of Old English swātþȳrel (literally “sweat hole”), which competed ...

PORK.e:
From Middle English pork, porc, via Anglo-Norman, from Old French porc (“swine, hog, pig; pork”), from Latin porcus (“domestic hog, pig”).
Cognate with Old English fearh (“piglet”). Doublet of farrow. Compare also other West Germanic words for pigs: Ferkel, Ferke, and varken.
Use...

PORN.e: Clipping of pornography. Attested from mid-20th century.

PORT.d: A place on the coast at which ships can shelter, or dock to load and unload cargo or passengers.
PORT.e: From Old English port, borrowed from Latin portus (“port, harbour”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *pértus (“crossing”) (and thus a distant doublet of ford). The directional sense, attested since at least the 1500s, derives from ancient vessels with the steering oar on the ...

POSE.e: From Middle English pose, from Old English ġeposu pl (“cold in the head; catarrh”, literally “(the) sneezes; (the) snorts”), from Old English pos, ġepos (“sneeze, snort”), from Proto-West Germanic *pos, from Proto-Germanic *pusą (“sneeze, snort”), from Proto-Germanic *pusōną, *pu...

POSH.e:
Unknown.
Most likely derived from Romani posh (“half”), either because posh-kooroona (“half a crown”) (originally a substantial sum of money) was used metaphorically for anything pricey or upper-class, or because posh-houri (“half-penny”) came to refer to money generally.
A perio...

POST.d: A long dowel or plank protruding from the ground; a fencepost; a lightpost.
POST.e: Inherited from Old English post (“pillar, door-post”) and Latin postis (“a post, a door-post”) through Old French. .

POSY.d: A flower; a small bouquet; a nosegay.

POTS.d: Plural of POT: A flat-bottomed vessel (usually metal) used for cooking food, possibly excluding saucepans (see usage notes).
POTS.e:
From Middle English pot, potte, from Old English pott (“pot”) and Old French pot (“pot”) (probably from Frankish *pott); both Old English and Frankish from Proto-Germanic *puttaz (“pot”), from Proto-Indo-European *budnós (“a type of vessel”).
Cognate with Saterland Frisian Pot (“...

POUR.d: To cause (liquid, or liquid-like substance) to flow in a stream, either out of a container or into it.
POUR.e:
From Middle English pouren (“to pour”), of uncertain origin. Perhaps from Old Northern French purer (“to sift (grain), pour out (water)”), from Latin pūrō (“to purify”), from pūrus (“pure”). Compare Middle Dutch afpuren (“to pour off, drain”).
To pour displaced several Middle Eng...

POUT.e: From Middle English pouten, probably from Scandinavian (compare Norwegian pute (“pillow, cushion”), dial. Swedish puta (“to be puffed out”), Danish pude (“pillow, cushion”)), from Proto-Germanic *pūto (“swollen”) (compare English eelpout, Dutch puit, Low German puddig (“inflated”...

POWS.d: Plural of POW: Initialism of prisoner of war.

PRAM.d: A small vehicle, usually covered, in which a newborn baby is pushed around in a lying position.

PRAT.d: A cunning or mischievous trick; a prank, a joke.
PRAT.e: From Middle English prat, from Old English præt, prætt (“trick, prank, craft, art, wile”), from Proto-West Germanic *prattu, from Proto-Germanic *prattuz (“boastful talk, deceit”), from Proto-Indo-European *brodno- (“to wander about”). Cognate with Saterland Frisian prat, Dutch p...

PRAY.d: To direct words, thoughts, or one's attention to a deity or any higher being, for the sake of adoration, thanks, petition for help, etc.
PRAY.e:
From Middle English preien, from Anglo-Norman preier, from Old French preier, proier (French prier), from Latin precārī, from prex, precis (“a prayer, a request”), from Proto-Italic *preks, from Proto-Indo-European *preḱ- (“to ask, woo”). Displaced native Old English gebiddan.
Co...

PRED.d: Past tense of PRE: Before (something significant).
PRED.e: From Latin prae (“in front of”); see pre-.

PRES.e: From Latin prae (“in front of”); see pre-.

PREY.d: That which is or may be seized by animals to be devoured.
PREY.e: From Middle English preye, prei, preyȝe, borrowed from Anglo-Norman and Old French preie, one of the variants of proie, from Latin praeda. Compare predator. Doublet of prede.

PRIG.d: A deliberately superior person; a person who demonstrates an exaggerated conformity or propriety, especially in an irritatingly arrogant or smug manner.
PRIG.e: UK 16th century. Of unknown origin. Earlier noun senses ("tinker" and "thief"), as hyponyms of "undesirable person", may have informed later senses ("conceited person").

PRIM.d: Of a person, their manner or appearance: Formal and precise; stiffly decorous.
PRIM.e:
Of uncertain origin.
In the verb sense, first appeared in Thomas D'Urfey's A Fool's Preferment in the year 1688.
In the noun sense, first appeared in A New Dictionary of the Terms Ancient and Modern of the Canting Crew in the year 1699, meaning "prig." Now obsolete.
In the adject...

PROA.d: A sailing vessel found in the waters of Micronesia and Indonesia; it has a single, large outrigger and a triangular sail.
PROA.e: From Malay perau, a variant of perahu. In some forms via Portuguese parão or Dutch prauw; in some forms assimilated to prow.

PROD.d: To poke, to push, to touch.
PROD.e: Alteration of earlier brod (perhaps through influence of poke; compare prog), from Middle English brodden (“to goad, incite, urge; to sprout”), from brod (“goad, nail; shoot, sprout”), from Old Norse broddr (“shaft, spike, thorn”), from Proto-Germanic *bruzdaz. Cognate with Icela...

PROP.d: An object placed against or under another, to support it; anything that supports.
PROP.e: From Middle English proppe (“a prop, support, support for a vine or plant”), from Middle Dutch proppe (“support, support for a vine, stopper for a bottle”). Compare Middle Low German proppe (“plug, stopper”), German Pfropfen (“plug”), Danish prop (“plug, stopper”).

PROW.d: The front part of a vessel.
PROW.e: From Middle French proue, proe, from Ligurian prua, proa, from Latin prōra, from Ancient Greek πρῷρα (prōîra).

PRYS.d: Plural of PRY: To peer closely and curiously, especially at something closed or not public.
PRYS.e: The verb is inherited from Middle English prien, pryen (“to look closely, peer into, pry, spy”) [and other forms], from Old English *prīwan, *prēowian (“to look narrowly, to squint at”), attested by Old English beprīwan, beprēwan (“to wink”); further etymology unknown, but probab...

PSIS.d: Plural of PSI: The twenty-third letter of Classical and Modern Greek and the twenty-fifth letter of Old and Ancient Greek.
PSIS.e: From Middle English psi, from Latin psī, from Ancient Greek ψεῖ (pseî), the name for the twenty-third letter of the alphabet (Ψ, ψ).

PSST.d: Implies that the speaker is sending secret or whispered information to another person.

PUBS.d: Plural of PUB: A public house where beverages, primarily alcoholic, may be bought and consumed, also providing food and sometimes entertainment such as live music or television.

PUCE.d: A brownish-purple color, sometimes more or less deep red or grayish.
PUCE.e: From French couleur puce, from Latin pūlex (“flea”).

PUCK.e:
From Middle English pouke, from Old English pūca (“goblin, demon”), from Proto-West Germanic *pūkō, from Proto-Germanic *pūkô (“a goblin, spook”), of uncertain origin.
Cognate with Old Norse púki (“devil”) (dialectal Swedish puke). Doublet of pooka.

PUFF.d: A sharp exhalation of a small amount of breath through the mouth.
PUFF.e: From Middle English puff, puf, from Old English pyf (“a blast of wind, puff”), imitative. Cognate with Middle Low German puf, pof.

PUGS.d: Plural of PUG: Senses relating to someone or something small.
PUGS.e: Origin unknown, possibly related to West Flemish pugge (“(adjective) small; (noun) short person; pet name derived from the first name Pugge”); though it is uncertain whether sense 1 (“senses relating to someone or something small”) and sense 2 (“senses relating to people”) are de...

PUJA.d: A religious ritual performed in South Asia as an act of worship.

PUKE.e: Probably imitative; or, alternatively from Proto-Germanic *pukaną (“to spit, puff”), from Proto-Indo-European *bew- (“to blow, swell”). If so, then cognate with German pfauchen, fauchen (“to hiss, spit”). Compare also Dutch spugen (“to spit, spit up”), German spucken (“to spit, p...

PUKU.d: A medium-sized antelope found in Central Africa (Kobus vardonii).

PULE.e: From French piauler, a variant of French piailler (“to chirp, cheep”). Compare Italian pigolare (“to cheep as a chicken”).

PULL.d: To apply a force to (an object) so that it comes toward the person or thing applying the force.
PULL.e: Verb from Middle English pullen, from Old English pullian (“to pull, draw, tug, pluck off”), of uncertain ultimate origin. Related to West Frisian pûlje (“to shell, husk”), Middle Dutch pullen (“to drink”), Middle Dutch polen (“to peel, strip”), Low German pulen (“to pick, pluck,...

PULP.d: A soft, moist, shapeless mass or matter.
PULP.e: From Middle English pulpe, from Latin pulpa.

PUMA.d: A mountain lion or cougar (Puma concolor).
PUMA.e: Borrowed from Spanish puma, from Quechua puma.

PUMP.d: A device for moving or compressing a liquid or gas.
PUMP.e:
From Middle English pumpe, possibly from Middle Dutch pompe (“pipe, water conduit”) or Middle Low German pumpe (“pump”), probably ultimately imitative.
Compare Dutch pompen, German pumpen, and Danish pompe; also Spanish bomba (“pump”).

PUNA.d: An alpine biological community in the central portion of the Andes in which short, coarse grass supports a Native American population.
PUNA.e: From Spanish puna, from Quechua puna.

PUNK.d: One who engages in sexual intercourse
PUNK.e: Uncertain. Possibly from punk (“rotten wood dust used as tinder”), attested since 1678, to anything worthless (attested since 1869) and then to any undesirable person (since 1908). The relatively tame 21st century usage of punk (“prank”, verb) was popularized by the American tele...

PUNS.d: Plural of PUN: To beat; strike with force; to ram; to pound, as in a mortar; reduce to powder, to pulverize.
PUNS.e: From Middle English ponnen, ponen, punen, from Old English punian, pūnian (“to pound, beat, bray, bruise, crush, grind”), from Proto-Germanic *punōną (“to break to pieces, pulverize”). See pound. As a kind of word play, from the notion of "beating" the words into place.

PUNT.d: A pontoon; a narrow shallow boat propelled by a pole.
PUNT.e: From Old English [Term?], from Latin pontō (“Gaulish flat-bottomed boat, pontoon”), from pons (“bridge”); readopted from Middle Low German punte (“ferry boat”) or Middle Dutch ponte (“ferry boat”) of the same origin.

PUNY.d: Of inferior significance, size, or strength; ineffective, small, weak.
PUNY.e:
Etymology tree
Proto-Indo-European *pós
Proto-Indo-European *-ti
Proto-Indo-European *pós-ti
Proto-Italic *posti
Latin poste
Latin post
Proto-Indo-European *íh₂
Latin ea
Latin posteā
Vulgar Latin *postius
Old French puis
Proto-Indo-European *ǵenh₁-
Proto-Indo-European *-tós
Proto...

PUPA.d: An insect in the development stage between larva and adult.
PUPA.e: Borrowed from New Latin, from a special use of Latin pūpa (“little girl; doll, puppet”). Doublet of pupe; compare also puppet, puppy.

PUPS.d: Plural of PUP: A young dog, wolf, fox, seal, bat or shark, or the young of certain other animals.

PURE.d: Free of flaws or imperfections; unsullied.
PURE.e: From Middle English pure, pur, from Old French pur, from Latin pūrus (“clean, free from dirt or filth, unmixed, plain”), from Proto-Indo-European *pewH- (“to cleanse, purify”). Displaced native Middle English lutter (“pure, clear, sincere”) (from Old English hlūtor, hluttor), Mid...

PURI.d: A type of unleavened bread from India and Pakistan, usually deep-fried.
PURI.e: From Hindi पूरी (pūrī), a kind of fried flatbread.

PURL.d: A particular stitch in knitting in which the working yarn is pulled through an existing stitch from front to back.
PURL.e: Unknown; apparently related to Scots and dialect pirl (“twist, ripple, whirl, spin”), and possibly to Older Scots pyrl ("thrust or poke at"). Compare Venetan pirlo, an embellishment where the woven threads are twisted together. May be unrelated to purfle, though the meanings are ...

PURR.d: To make a vibrating sound in its throat when contented or in certain other conditions.

PUSH.d: To apply a force to (an object) such that it moves away from the person or thing applying the force.
PUSH.e: From Middle English pushen, poshen, posson, borrowed from Middle French pousser (Modern French pousser) from Old French poulser, from Latin pulsare (“to beat, strike”), frequentative of pellere (past participle pulsus). Doublet of pulsate and pulse (verb). Partly displaced native...

PUSS.d: Plural of PUS: A whitish-yellow or yellow substance composed primarily of dead white blood cells and dead pyogenic bacteria, normally found in regions of bacterial infection.

PUTS.d: third-person singular simple present indicative of put

PUTT.d: The act of tapping a golf ball lightly on a putting green.
PUTT.e: Borrowed from Scots putt (“to put”). Compare Middle Dutch putten (“to dig a pit”). The Old English putian (“to push; thrust; put; place”) derivation is commonly assumed, although no longer valid. In Dutch, the word is instanced in a description of golf in an early seventeenth-cen...

PYRE.d: A funeral pile; a combustible heap on which corpses are burned.
PYRE.e: Learned borrowing from Latin pyra (“pyre, funeral pile”), from Ancient Greek πυρά (purá), from πῦρ (pûr, “fire”). Doublet of fire.

PYRO.e: Shortening of a word starting with pyro-, ultimately from Ancient Greek πῦρ (pûr, “fire”).

QUAD.e:
Shortened, via clipping or abbreviation, from various English terms. Ultimately related to Latin quattuor (“4”); compare quadri-, quadruple.
The typography senses are from the abbreviation quad. for obsolete quadrat; the keyboard command comes from the verb sense.

QUAY.d: A stone or concrete structure on navigable water used for loading and unloading vessels; a wharf.
QUAY.e: The current spelling replaced the spelling key in the 1690s to emulate the spelling but (at least originally) not the pronunciation of the equivalent modern French quai. From Middle English kay, key, kaye, keye, from Old French kay, cail, from Gaulish *kagyum, cagiíun (“enclosure...

QUID.e: Borrowed from Latin quid (“what, something”), neuter singular of quis (“who”).

QUIP.d: A smart, sarcastic turn or jest; a taunt; a severe retort or comeback; a gibe.
QUIP.e: From a shortening of earlier quippy, perhaps from Latin quippe (“indeed”), ultimately quid (“what”).

QUIT.d: Released from obligation, penalty, etc; free, clear, or rid.
QUIT.e:
From Middle English quiten, quyten, from Anglo-Norman quitter, Old French quitter, from quitte (“acquitted, quit”), ultimately from Latin quietus, which itself derives from Proto-Indo-European *kʷyéh₁-ti-s, from *kʷyeh₁- (“to rest”). Doublet of coy, quite, quiet, and quietus.
Com...

QUIZ.d: An odd, puzzling or absurd person or thing.
QUIZ.e:
Attested since the 1780s, of unknown origin.
* The Century Dictionary suggests it was originally applied to a popular toy, from a dialectal variant of whiz.
* The Random House Dictionary suggests the original sense was "odd person" (circa 1780).
* Others suggest the meaning "hoax...

QUOD.d: A quadrangle or court, as of a prison; a prison.
QUOD.e: Abbreviation of quadrangle; originally (17th century) referring to the quadrangles of Newgate Prison, London.

RABI.e:
Borrowed from Hindustani ربیع (rabī) / रबी (rabī),
from Persian ربیع (rabi'), from Arabic رَبِيع (rabīʕ, “spring”).

RACE.d: A contest between people, animals, vehicles, etc. where the goal is to be the first to reach some objective.
RACE.e: From Middle English race, partially from Old English rǣs (“a race, swift or violent running, rush, onset”), from Proto-West Germanic *rās; and partially from Old Norse rás (“a running, race”); both from Proto-Germanic *rēsō (“a course”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₁reh₁s- (“to fl...

RACK.d: A series of one or more shelves, stacked one above the other.
RACK.e: From Middle English rakke, rekke, from Middle Dutch rac, recke, rec (Dutch rek), see rekken.

RACY.e: From race (“having a characteristic taste (of wines, fruits, etc.)”) + -y.

RADS.d: Plural of RAD: Clipping of radical (“excellent”).

RAFF.d: A disorderly heap; a jumble; a large quantity; lumber; refuse.
RAFF.e: From Middle English raf, from Old French raffer, of Germanic origin; compare German raffen, akin to rap (“to snatch”). Compare riffraff, rip (“to tear”).

RAFT.d: A flat-bottomed craft able to float and drift on water, used for transport or as a waterborne platform.
RAFT.e: Late Middle English, of North Germanic origin, from West Old Norse raptr, from Proto-Germanic *raf-tra-, from Proto-Indo-European *rap-tro-, from *rep- (“stake, beam”). See also Norwegian raft (“beam, rafter”), Danish raft (“thin pole”). Compare also Albanian trap (“raft, ferry”)...

RAGA.d: Any of various melodic forms used in Indian classical music, or a piece of music composed in such a form.

RAGE.e:
From Middle English rage, from Anglo-Norman rage, from Late Latin rabia, from Classical Latin rabiēs (“anger, fury”). Doublet of rabies.
Displaced native Middle English wode, from Old English wōd ("madness, fury, rage"; compare Modern dialectal English wood (“mad, insane, furious...

RAGS.e: From Middle English ragge, from Old English ragg (suggested by derivative raggiġ (“shaggy; bristly; ragged”)), from Old Norse rǫgg (“tuft; shagginess”), from Proto-Germanic *rawwa-, probably related to *rūhaz. Cognate with Swedish ragg. Related to rug.

RAID.d: A quick hostile or predatory incursion or invasion in a battle.
RAID.e: From Scots raid, from Northern Middle English rade, from Old English rād (“a riding, an expedition on horseback, road”), whence also the inherited English road (“way, street”). The earlier senses of “a riding, expedition, raid” fell into disuse in Early Modern English, but were r...

RAIL.d: A horizontal bar extending between supports and used for support or as a barrier; a railing.
RAIL.e: From Middle English rail, rayl, *reȝel, *reȝol (found in reȝolsticke (“a ruler”)), partly from Old English regol (“a ruler, straight bar”) and partly from Old French reille; both from Latin regula (“rule, bar”), from regō (“to rule, to guide, to govern”); see regular. Doublet of ...

RAIN.d: Condensed water falling from a cloud.
RAIN.e:
From Middle English reyn, rein, from Old English reġn, from Proto-West Germanic *regn, from Proto-Germanic *regną, of uncertain origin. Possibly from pre-Germanic *Hréǵ-no-, from Proto-Indo-European *Hreǵ- (“to flow”), although the consonant reflexes don't match.
Cognates
Cognate...

RAKE.d: A garden tool with a row of pointed teeth fixed to a long handle, used for collecting debris, grass, etc., for flattening the ground, or for loosening soil; also, a similar wheel-mounted tool drawn by a horse or a tractor.
RAKE.e:
From Middle English rake [and other forms], from Old English raca, racu, ræce (“tool with a row of pointed teeth, rake”), from Proto-Germanic *rakō, *rekô (“tool with a row of pointed teeth, rake”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₃reǵ- (“to straighten, right oneself”).
Cognates
The E...

RALE.d: An abnormal clicking, rattling or crackling sound, made by one or both lungs and heard with a stethoscope, caused by the popping open of airways collapsed by fluid or exudate, or sometimes by pulmonary edema.

RAMP.d: An inclined surface that connects two levels; an incline.
RAMP.e: From French rampe, from Middle French rampe, deverbal of ramper, from Old French ramper (“to crawl, climb, scale up”), from Frankish *hrampōn (“to contract oneself, wrinkle, rumple, crumple, curve”), from Proto-Germanic *hrimpaną (“to shrivel, shrink”). Cognate with German Rampf ...

RAMS.d: Plural of RAM: Acronym of random-access memory.

RAND.d: The border of an area of land, now especially marshland.
RAND.e: From Middle English rand, from Old English rand (“edge, border, margin, rim, shore”), from Proto-West Germanic *rand, from Proto-Germanic *randaz, *randō (“edge, rim, crust”), from Proto-Indo-European *rem- (“to rest, prop or support oneself”). Cognate with Dutch rand (“edge, bor...

RANG.d: simple past of ring (only in senses related to a bell — etymology 2)

RANI.e: From Hindustani رانی (rānī) / रानी (rānī), from Sanskrit राज्ञी (rā́jñī, “queen, princess”). Doublet of Regina.

RANK.d: Strong; powerful; capable of acting or being used with great effect; energetic; vigorous; headstrong.
RANK.e: From Middle English rank (“strong, proud”), from Old English ranc (“proud, haughty, arrogant, insolent, forward, overbearing, showy, ostentatious, splendid, bold, valiant, noble, brave, strong, full-grown, mature”), from Proto-West Germanic *rank, from Proto-Germanic *rankaz (“st...

RANT.d: To speak or shout at length in uncontrollable anger.
RANT.e: From Dutch ranten, randen (“to talk nonsense, rave”), from Middle Dutch ranten (“to rant, babble, goof around”), of uncertain origin; but apparently related to Middle High German ranzen (“to dance, jump around, frolic”), German ranzen (“to be ardent, be in heat, copulate, mate, r...

RAPE.d: The act of forcing sex upon another person without their consent or against their will; originally coitus forced by a man on a woman, but now generally any sex act forced by any person upon another person, regardless of gender; by extension, any non-consensual sex act forced on, perpetrated by, or forced to penetrate any being.
RAPE.e: From Middle English rapen, rappen (“to abduct; ravish; seduce; rape; seize; snatch; carry off; transport”), probably from Latin rapiō (verb), possibly through or influenced by Anglo-Norman rap, rape (noun) (compare also ravish). But compare Swedish rappa (“to snatch, seize, carry...

RAPS.d: Plural of RAP: A sharp blow with something hard.
RAPS.e: From Middle English rap, rappe, of North Germanic origin, related to Norwegian rapp (“a blow, strike, lash”), Swedish rapp (“a blow, lash, crack”), Danish rap (“a tap, smart, blow”). Compare Old English hreppan (“to touch, treat”). More at rape.

RAPT.e: Borrowed from Latin raptus, past participle of rapio (“to seize”).

RARE.e: From Middle English rare, from Old French rare, rere (“rare, uncommon”), from Latin rārus (“loose, spaced apart, thin, infrequent”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₁reh₁- (“friable, thin”). Replaced native Middle English gesen (“rare, scarce”) (from Old English gǣsne), Middle English...

RASE.d: To be extremely angry; to rage; specifically, of a dog or wolf: to snarl in rage.
RASE.e: From Late Middle English rasen, rasyn (“to rage; to enrage (?)”), probably from Middle Dutch râsen, râzen (“to be extremely angry, rage; to be mad, rave; to talk nonsense; of a dog: to be rabid”), from Old Dutch *rāson (modern Dutch razen), from Proto-West Germanic *rāsōn (“to ru...

RASH.d: Acting too quickly without considering the consequences and risks; not careful; hasty.
RASH.e: The adjective is derived from Middle English rash, rasch (“hasty, headstrong, rash”) [and other forms], probably from Old English *ræsċ (“rash”) (found in derivatives such as ræsċan (“to move rapidly; to flicker; to flash; to glitter; to quiver”), ræsċettan (“to crackle, sparkle”...

RASP.d: A coarse file or filelike tool, on which the cutting prominences are distinct points raised by the oblique stroke of a sharp punch, instead of lines raised by a chisel, as on the true file.
RASP.e:
From Middle English raspen, from Old French rasper, from Frankish *hraspōn, from Proto-Germanic *hraspōną, related to Proto-Germanic *hrespaną (“to tear”). Compare Old High German raspōn (“to gather, rake”), Old English ġehrespan (“to tear”).
The noun is from Middle French raspe.

RATA.d: Any of various New Zealand plants of the genus Metrosideros.
RATA.e:
]
From Maori rātā or cognate Tahitian rātā (“tree of genus Metrosideros”). Compare Tahitian puarātā (“Metrosideros collina”).

RATE.e: From Middle English rate, from Old French rate, from Medieval Latin rata, from Latin prō ratā parte (“according to a fixed part”), from ratus (“fixed”), from rērī (“think, deem, judge, estimate", originally "reckon, calculate”).

RATS.d: Plural of RAT: A medium-sized rodent belonging to the genus Rattus.
RATS.e: From Middle English ratte, rat, rotte, from Old English rætt, from Proto-West Germanic *ratt, from Proto-Germanic *rattaz, *rattō (compare West Frisian rôt, Dutch rat), of uncertain origin, possibly from Proto-Indo-European *Hreh₃d- (“to scrape, scratch, gnaw”). However, the rat ...

RAVE.d: An enthusiastic review (such as of a play).
RAVE.e: From Middle English raven (“to rave; talk like a madman”), from Old French raver, variant of resver, of uncertain origin. Compare rave below, and rove.

RAWS.d: Plural of RAW: (of food) Not cooked.
RAWS.e:
From Middle English rawe, raw, rau, from Old English hrēaw (“raw, uncooked”), from Proto-West Germanic *hrau, from Proto-Germanic *hrawaz, *hrēwaz (“raw”), from Proto-Indo-European *krewh₂- (“raw meat, fresh blood”).
Cognate with Scots raw (“raw”), Dutch rauw (“raw”), German roh ...

RAYS.d: Plural of RAY: A beam of light or radiation.
RAYS.e: Via Middle English, borrowed from Old French rai, from Latin radius (“staff, stake, spoke”). Doublet of radius.

RAZE.d: To level or tear down (a building, a town, etc.) to the ground; to demolish.
RAZE.e: The verb is derived from Middle English rasen, racen, rase (“to scrape; to shave; to erase; to pull; to strip off; to pluck or tear out; to root out (a tree, etc.); to pull away, snatch; to pull down; to knock down; to rend, tear apart; to pick clean, strip; to cleave, slice; to ...

READ.d: To look at and interpret letters or other information that is written.
READ.e:
From Middle English reden, from Old English rǣdan (“to counsel, advise, consult; interpret, read”), from Proto-West Germanic *rādan, from Proto-Germanic *rēdaną (“advise, counsel”), from Proto-Indo-European *Hreh₁dʰ- (“to arrange”).
Cognate with Scots rede, red (“to advise, couns...

REAL.d: True, genuine, not merely nominal or apparent.
REAL.e: From Middle English real, from Old French reel, from Late Latin reālis (“actual”), from Latin rēs (“matter, thing”), from Proto-Indo-European *reh₁ís (“wealth, goods”). Doublet of realis.

REAM.d: Cream; also, the creamlike froth on ale or other liquor; froth or foam in general.
REAM.e:
From Middle English reme, rem, from Old English rēam (“cream”), from Proto-West Germanic *raum, from Proto-Germanic *raumaz (“cream”), from Proto-Indo-European *réwgʰmn̥ (“to sour [milk]”).
Cognate with Saterland Frisian Room (“cream”), West Frisian rjemme (“cream”), Dutch room (...

REAP.d: To cut (for example a grain) with a sickle, scythe, or reaping machine
REAP.e: From Middle English repen, from Old English rēopan, rēpan, variants of Old English rīpan (“to reap”), from Proto-West Germanic *rīpan, from Proto-Germanic *rīpaną (compare West Frisian repe, Norwegian ripa (“to score, scratch”)), from Proto-Indo-European *h₁reyb- (“to snatch”).

REAR.d: To bring up to maturity, as offspring; to educate; to instruct; to foster.
REAR.e: From Middle English reren (“to raise”), from Old English rǣran (“to raise, set upright, promote, exalt, begin, create, give rise to, excite, rouse, arouse, stir up”), from Proto-West Germanic *raiʀijan, from Proto-Germanic *raizijaną, *raisijaną (“to cause to rise, raise”), from ...

RECK.d: To take account of (someone or something); to care for; to consider, to heed, to regard.
RECK.e: From Middle English recken, rekken, reken, from Old Norse rœkja (compare Old English rēċċan, rēċan (“to care, reck, take care of, be interested in, care for, desire”); whence English retch), from Proto-Germanic *rōkijaną (“to care, take care”), from Proto-Indo-European *rēǵ-, *rē...

REDS.d: Plural of RED: The colour of the setting sun, blood, and strawberries; the colour which is evoked by the longest visible wavelengths (between about 625–740 nm), and a primary additive colour.
REDS.e:
From Middle English red, from Old English rēad, from Proto-West Germanic *raud, from Proto-Germanic *raudaz from Proto-Indo-European *h₁rowdʰós, from the root *h₁rewdʰ-.
Cognates
See also West Frisian read, Low German root, rood, rot, rod, Dutch rood, German rot, Danish and Norwe...

REED.d: Any of various types of tall stiff perennial grass-like plants growing together in groups near water.
REED.e:
From Middle English red, reed, from Old English hrēod, from Proto-West Germanic *hreud, of uncertain origin.
Akin to Saterland Frisian Rait (“reed”), West Frisian reid (“reed”), Dutch riet (“reed”), German Ried (“reed”). No cognates in North Germanic languages, but the existence ...

REEF.d: A chain or range of rocks, sand, or coral lying at or near the surface of the water.
REEF.e: From earlier riff, from Middle English rif, from Old Norse rif (“rib, reef”), from Proto-Germanic *ribją (“rib, reef”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₁rebʰ- (“arch, ceiling, cover”). Dutch rif (“reef”), Low German riff, reff (“reef”), German Riff (“reef, ledge”) are also borrowed fr...

REEK.e:
From Middle English rek, reke (“smoke”), from Old English rēc, from Proto-West Germanic *rauki, from Proto-Germanic *raukiz, from Proto-Indo-European *rowgi-.
See also West Frisian reek, riik, Dutch rook, Low German Röök, German Rauch, Danish røg, Norwegian Bokmål røyk; also Lith...

REEL.e: From Middle English reel, reele, from Old English rēol, hrēol, from Proto-West Germanic *hrehul, from Proto-Germanic *hrehulaz, *hrahilaz, from Proto-Indo-European *krek- (“to weave, beat”). Cognate with Icelandic ræl, hræll.

REFS.d: Plural of REF: Clipping of referee.

REIN.d: A strap or rope attached to a bridle or bit, used to control a horse, animal or young child.
REIN.e:
From Middle English rein, reyne, from Anglo-Norman reyne, resne, from Early Medieval Latin retina, ultimately from Classical Latin retineō (“hold back”), from re- + teneō (“keep, hold”). Compare modern French rêne.
Displaced native Old English brīdel (“bridle, rein”), Old English...

RELY.d: to trust; to have confidence in; to depend.
RELY.e: From Middle English relien, from Old French relier (“fasten, attach, rally, oblige”), from Latin religo (“fasten, bind fast”), from re- + ligo.

REMS.d: Plural of REM: Initialism of rapid eye movement.
REMS.e: From the initial letters of rapid eye movement.

REND.d: To separate into parts with force or sudden violence; to split; to burst.
REND.e: From Middle English renden, from Old English rendan (“to rend, tear, cut, lacerate, cut down”), from Proto-West Germanic *(h)randijan (“to tear”), of uncertain origin. Believed by some to be the causative of Proto-Germanic *hrindaną (“to push”), from Proto-Indo-European *ḱret-, *...

RENT.d: A payment made by a tenant at intervals in order to lease a property.
RENT.e: From Middle English rent, rente, from Old French rente, from Early Medieval Latin rendita, from Late Latin rendere, from Latin reddere.

REPO.d: Clipping of repossession, most commonly of a vehicle, house or condominium.

REPS.d: Plural of REP: Clipping of reputation.
REPS.e: Clippings of various words beginning with rep.

REST.d: Relief from work or activity by sleeping; sleep.
REST.e: From Middle English rest, reste, from Old English ræst, from Proto-West Germanic *rastu, from Proto-Germanic *rastō, from Proto-Indo-European *ros-, *res-, *erH- (“rest”). Cognate with West Frisian rêst (“rest”), Dutch rust (“rest”), German Rast (“rest”), Swedish rast (“rest”), N...

RETS.d: Plural of RET: To prepare (flax, hemp etc.) for further processing by soaking, which facilitates separation of fibers from the woody parts of the stem.
RETS.e: From Middle English retten, reten; perhaps from Middle Dutch rēten, reeten (compare Middle Low German rōten; Middle High German rōzen), or from Old Norse reyta (compare Norwegian røyta, Swedish röta); all from Proto-Germanic *rautijaną (“to make mellow or soft”), from Proto-Indo-...

REVS.d: Plural of REV: To increase the speed of a motor, or to operate at a higher speed.

RHEA.d: A large flightless bird of the order Rheiformes, native to South America.
RHEA.e: Learned borrowing from taxonomic name Rhea, from Ancient Greek Ῥέα (Rhéa, “the mother of Zeus in Greek mythology”).

RHOS.d: Plural of RHO: The seventeenth letter of the Modern Greek and Classical alphabets and the nineteenth letter of Old and Ancient.
RHOS.e: From the name of the Ancient Greek letter ῥῶ (rhô).

RIAL.d: The official currencies of Iran, Oman, and Yemen.
RIAL.e: Borrowed from Persian ریال (riyâl) (in the case of Iran) and a variant transliteration of Arabic رِيَال (riyāl) (in the case of Oman and Yemen), from Spanish real. Doublet of real, royal, and regal.

RIBS.d: Plural of RIB: Any of a series of long curved bones occurring in 12 pairs in humans and other animals and extending from the spine to or toward the sternum.
RIBS.e:
From Middle English rib, ribbe, from Old English ribb (“rib”), from Proto-West Germanic *ribi, from Proto-Germanic *ribją (“rib, reef”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₁rebʰ- (“arch, ceiling, cover”).
Cognate with Dutch rib (“rib”), Norwegian ribbe (“sparerib”), Norwegian ribben (“ri...

RICE.d: Cereal plants, Oryza sativa of the grass family whose seeds are used as food.
RICE.e: From Middle English rys, from Old French ris, from Old Italian riso, risi, from Byzantine Greek ὄρυζα (óruza), from an Eastern Iranian language related to Middle Persian blnc (*brinǰ), Northern Kurdish riz (beyond Euphrates) and Zazaki riz. Theorized to come to Iranian languages ...

RICH.d: Wealthy: having a lot of money and possessions.
RICH.e: From Middle English riche (“strong, powerful, rich”), from Old English rīċe (“powerful, mighty, great, high-ranking, rich, wealthy, strong, potent”), from Proto-West Germanic *rīkī (“powerful, rich”), from Proto-Germanic *rīkijaz (“kingly, powerful, rich”), from Proto-Germanic *r...

RICK.d: Straw, hay etc. stored in a stack for winter fodder, commonly protected with thatch.
RICK.e: From Middle English *rykke, from Old English hrycce (“rick, heap, pile”), cognate with Scots ruk (“rick”), Norwegian ruka (“rick, haystack”). Related also to Old English hrēac (“rick, stack”), from Proto-Germanic *hraukaz (“heap”). Further relations: Dutch rook, Icelandic hraukur...

RIDE.d: To transport oneself by sitting on and directing a horse, later also a bicycle etc.
RIDE.e:
From Middle English riden, from Old English rīdan, from Proto-West Germanic *rīdan, from Proto-Germanic *rīdaną, from Proto-Indo-European *Hreydʰ-, from Proto-Indo-European *h₃reyH-.
Cognates
From Proto-Germanic: North Frisian ride (“to ride”), Saterland Frisian riede (“to ride”)...

RIDS.d: Plural of RID: Followed by of: to free (oneself or someone, or a place) from an annoyance or hindrance.
RIDS.e: The verb is derived from Middle English ridden (“to remove debris, obstructions, etc., from (a place), to clear; to complete (something unfinished); to free (someone or something); to relieve (someone); etc.”), probably from Old English *ryddan (“to remove debris, obstructions, e...

RIFE.d: Widespread, common, prevalent, current (mainly of unpleasant or harmful things).
RIFE.e: From Middle English rife, from Old English rīfe, rȳfe (“rife, abundant, frequent”), from Proto-West Germanic *rīb, from Proto-Germanic *rībaz (“generous”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₁reyp- (“to tear (off), rip”). Cognate with West Frisian rju (“rife, much”), Dutch rijf (“abundan...

RIFF.d: A repeated melody line in a song, usually instrumental but sometimes vocal.
RIFF.e: Uncertain. Perhaps a clipping of riffle, or an alteration of refrain.

RIFT.e: From Middle English rift, of North Germanic origin; akin to Danish rift, Norwegian Bokmål rift (“breach”), Old Norse rífa (“to tear”). More at rive.

RIGS.d: Plural of RIG: The rigging of a sailing ship or other such craft.
RIGS.e: From Early Modern English rygge, probably of North Germanic origin. Compare Norwegian rigge (“to bind up; wrap around; rig; equip”), Swedish dialectal rigga (“to rig a horse”), Faroese rigga (“to rig; to equip and fit; to make s.th. function”). Possibly from Proto-Germanic *rik- ...

RILE.d: To stir or move from a state of calm or order.
RILE.e: From a dialectal pronunciation of roil.

RILL.d: A very small brook; a streamlet; a creek, rivulet.
RILL.e: From or akin to West Frisian ril (“rill; a narrow channel”), Dutch ril (“rill; gully; trench; watercourse”), German Low German Rille, Rill (“a small channel; brook; furrow”), German Rille (“a groove; furrow”).

RIME.d: Archaic in the form rimes: originally, any frozen dew forming a white deposit on exposed surfaces; hoar frost (sense 1).
RIME.e: The noun is derived from Middle English rim, rime, rym, ryme (“hoar frost; rime”), from Old English hrīm (“frost”), from Proto-West Germanic *hrīm (“rime; hoar frost”), from Proto-Germanic *hrīmą (North Germanic), *hrīmaz, *hrīmô (“rime; hoar frost”), probably from Proto-Indo-Eur...

RIMS.d: Plural of RIM: An edge around something, especially when circular.
RIMS.e: From Middle English rim, rym, rime, from Old English rima (“rim, edge, border, bank, coast”), from Proto-Germanic *rimô, *rembô (“edge, border”), possibly from Proto-Indo-European *rem-, *remə- (“to rest, support, be based”). Cognate with Saterland Frisian Rim (“plank, wooden cro...

RIND.e: From Middle English rind, rinde, from Old English rind and rinde (“treebark, crust”), from Proto-West Germanic *rindā, from Proto-Germanic *rindō, *rindǭ (“crust, rind”), from Proto-Indo-European *rem- (“to come to rest, support or prop oneself”). Cognate with German Rinde (“bark...

RING.d: A solid object in the shape of a circle.
RING.e: From Middle English ryng, from Old English hring (“ring, circle”), from Proto-West Germanic *hring, from Proto-Germanic *hringaz (“ring”), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)krengʰ-, extended nasalized form of *(s)ker- (“to turn, bend”). Doublet of rank and rink, as well as indirectly ...

RINK.d: A man, especially a warrior or hero.
RINK.e:
From Middle English rink, renk, from Old English rinc (“man, warrior, hero”), from Proto-Germanic *rankiz (“upright man”), from *rankaz (“straight, upright”), from Proto-Indo-European *reǵ- (“straight, direct”).
Cognate with Scots rink, renk (“man, warrior, hero”), Old Saxon rink...

RIOT.d: A tumultuous disturbance of the public peace by a large group of people, often involving violence or damage to property.
RIOT.e:
From Middle English riot (“debauched living, dissipation”), from Old French riote (“debate”), from rioter (“to quarrel”), perhaps related to riboter or from Latin rugio (“I roar”).
Compare French riotte and Occitan riòta.

RIPE.d: Ready for reaping or gathering; having attained perfection; mature.
RIPE.e: From Middle English ripe, rype, from Old English rīpe (“ripe, mature”), from Proto-West Germanic *rīpī, from Proto-Germanic *rīpijaz, *rīpiz, from Proto-Indo-European *h₁reyb- (“to snatch”). Cognate with West Frisian ryp (“ripe”), Dutch rijp (“ripe”), German reif (“ripe”). Relate...

RIPS.d: Plural of RIP: To divide or separate the parts of (especially something flimsy, such as paper or fabric), by cutting or tearing; to tear off or out by violence.
RIPS.e:
From Middle English rippen, from earlier ryppen (“to pluck”), ultimately from Proto-Germanic *rupjaną, *ruppōną, intensive of *raupijaną, causative of Proto-Indo-European *roub- ~ *reub-, variant of *Hrewp- (“to break”).
See also West Frisian rippe, ripje, roppe, ropje (“to rip”)...

RISE.d: To move, or appear to move, physically upwards relative to the ground.
RISE.e:
From Middle English risen, from Old English rīsan, from Proto-West Germanic *rīsan, from Proto-Germanic *rīsaną, from Proto-Indo-European *h₁rey- (“to rise, arise”). According to Kroonen (2013), from Proto-Indo-European *h₃er- (“to stir, rise”). See also raise.
Cognates
Cognate w...

RISK.d: The probability of a negative outcome to a decision or event.
RISK.e:
From earlier risque, from Middle French risque, from Old Italian risco (“risk”) (modern Italian rischio) and rischiare (“to run into danger”). Displaced native Old English pleoh (“risk”) and plēon (“to risk”).
speculation on earlier roots
Most dictionaries consider the etymology ...

RITE.e: Via Middle English and Old French, from Latin ritus.

RIVE.d: To tear apart by force; to rend; to split; to cleave.
RIVE.e:
From Middle English riven (“to rive”), of North Germanic origin, from Old Norse rífa (“to rend, tear apart”), from Proto-Germanic *rīfaną (“to tear, scratch”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₁reyp- (“to crumble, tear”).
Cognate with Danish rive (“to tear”), Old Frisian rīva (“to tear...

ROAD.d: A way used for travelling between places, originally one wide enough to allow foot passengers and horses to travel, now (US) usually one surfaced with asphalt or concrete and designed to accommodate many vehicles travelling in both directions. In the UK both senses are heard: a country road is the same as a country lane.
ROAD.e: From Middle English rode, rade (“ride, journey”), from Old English rād (“riding, hostile incursion”), from Proto-West Germanic *raidu, from Proto-Germanic *raidō (“a ride”), from Proto-Indo-European *reydʰ- (“to ride”). Doublet of raid, acquired from Scots. Cognates include West ...

ROAM.d: To wander or travel freely and with no specific destination.
ROAM.e: From Middle English romen, from Old English rāmian, from Proto-Germanic *raimōną (“to wander”), from *raim- (“to move, raise”), from *h₃reyH- (“to move, lift, flow”). Akin to Old English ārǣman (“to arise, stand up, lift up”), Old High German rāmēn (“to aim”) ( > archaic German r...

ROAR.d: To make a loud, deep cry, especially from pain, anger, or other strong emotion.
ROAR.e:
From Middle English roren, raren, from Old English rārian (“to roar; wail; lament”), from Proto-West Germanic *rairōn, from Proto-Germanic *rairōną (“to bellow; roar”), from Proto-Indo-European *rey- (“to shout; bellow; yell; bark”), perhaps of imitative origin.
Cognate with Sate...

ROBE.d: A long loose outer garment, often signifying honorary stature.
ROBE.e: From Middle English robe, roobe, from Old French robe, robbe, reube (“booty, spoils of war, robe, garment”), from Frankish *rouba, *rauba (“booty, spoils, stolen clothes”, literally “things taken”), from Proto-Germanic *raubō, *raubaz, *raubą (“booty, that which is stripped or ca...

ROBS.d: Plural of ROB: To steal from, especially using force or violence.
ROBS.e: From Middle English robben, from Anglo-Norman robber, from Late Latin raubāre, from Frankish *raubōn (compare Dutch roven) and Old High German roubōn, raubōn (“to rob, steal, plunder”), from Proto-Germanic *raubōną. Doublet of reave.

ROCK.e: Inherited from Middle English rocke, rokke (“rock formation”), from Old English *rocc (“rock”), as in Old English stānrocc (“high stone rock, peak, obelisk”), and also later from Anglo-Norman roque, (compare Modern French roc, roche, rocher), from Medieval Latin rocca (attested 7...

RODS.d: Plural of ROD: A straight, round stick, shaft, bar, cane, or staff.
RODS.e: From Middle English rodde, from Old English *rodd or *rodde (attested in dative plural roddum (“rod, pole”)), of uncertain origin, but probably from Proto-Germanic *rudd- (“stick, club”), from Proto-Indo-European *rewdʰ- (“to clear land”). Compare Old Norse rudda (“club”). For th...

ROED.d: Past tense of ROE: Eggs of fish.
ROED.e:
From Middle English rowe, rowne, roun, rawne, from Old English *hrogn (“spawn, fish eggs, roe”), from Proto-Germanic *hrugnaz, *hrugną (“spawn, roe”), from Proto-Indo-European *krek- (“(frog) spawn”).
Cognate with Dutch roge (“roe”), German Low German Rögen (“roe”), German Rogen ...

ROES.d: Plural of ROE: Eggs of fish.
ROES.e:
From Middle English rowe, rowne, roun, rawne, from Old English *hrogn (“spawn, fish eggs, roe”), from Proto-Germanic *hrugnaz, *hrugną (“spawn, roe”), from Proto-Indo-European *krek- (“(frog) spawn”).
Cognate with Dutch roge (“roe”), German Low German Rögen (“roe”), German Rogen ...

ROIL.d: To render turbid by stirring up the dregs or sediment of.
ROIL.e: Origin uncertain. Possibly from French or Middle French rouiller (“to rust, make muddy”), from Old French rouil (“mud, rust”), from Vulgar Latin *robicula, from Latin robigo (“rust, blight”)

ROLE.d: A character or part played by a performer or actor.
ROLE.e: From French rôle, from Middle French rolle, from Old French role, from Medieval Latin rotulus. Doublet of roll and rotulus.

ROLL.d: To revolve by turning over and over; to move by turning on a horizontal axis; to impel forward with a revolving motion on a supporting surface.
ROLL.e: From Middle English rollen, partly from Old French roller, roler, röeler, röoler, from Medieval Latin rotulāre (“to roll; to revolve”), from Latin rotula (“a little wheel”), diminutive of rota (“a wheel”); partly from Anglo-Latin rollāre, from the same ultimate source.

ROMP.d: To play about roughly, energetically or boisterously.

ROOD.d: A crucifix, cross, especially in a church.
ROOD.e:
From Middle English rode, rood (“cross”), from Old English rōd (“cross”), from Proto-Germanic *rōdō, *rōdǭ (“rod, pole”), from Proto-Indo-European *rōt-, *reh₁t- (“bar, beam, stem”).
Cognate with German Rute (“rod, cane, pole”), Norwegian roda (“rod”). Largely displaced by cross....

ROOF.d: The external covering at the top of a building.
ROOF.e: From Middle English rof, from Old English hrōf (“roof, ceiling; top, summit; heaven, sky”), from Proto-Germanic *hrōfą (“roof”).

ROOK.d: A European bird, Corvus frugilegus, of the crow family.
ROOK.e: * Inherited from Middle English rok, roke, from Old English hrōc, from Proto-West Germanic *hrōk, from Proto-Germanic *hrōkaz (compare Old Norse hrókr, Saterland Frisian Rouk, Dutch roek, obsolete German Ruch), from Proto-Indo-European *kerk- (“crow, raven”) (compare Old Irish ce...

ROOM.d: An opportunity or scope (to do something).
ROOM.e: From Middle English roum, from Old English rūm (“room, space”), from Proto-West Germanic *rūm (“room”), from Proto-Germanic *rūmą (“room”), from Proto-Indo-European *(H)rewH-.

ROOT.d: The part of a plant, generally underground, that anchors and supports the plant body, absorbs and stores water and nutrients, and in some plants is able to perform vegetative reproduction.
ROOT.e:
PIE word
 *wréh₂ds
From Middle English rote, root, roote (“the underground part of a plant”), from late Old English rōt, from Old Norse rót (Icelandic rót), from Proto-Germanic *wrōts, from Proto-Indo-European *wréh₂ds (“root”); Doublet of wort, radish, and radix.

ROPE.d: Thick strings, yarn, monofilaments, metal wires, or strands of other cordage that are twisted together to form a stronger line.
ROPE.e: From Middle English rop, rope, from Old English rāp (“rope, cord, cable”), from Proto-West Germanic *raip, from Proto-Germanic *raipaz, *raipą (“rope, cord, band, ringlet”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₁roypnós (“strap, band, rope”), from *h₁reyp- (“to peel off, tear; border, edge...

ROSE.d: A shrub of the genus Rosa, with red, pink, white or yellow flowers.
ROSE.e:
From Middle English rose, roose, from Old English rōse, but with its vowel influenced by Old French rose, both from Latin rosa.
cognates and more remote and uncertain etymology
The Latin is of uncertain origin, but likely via Oscan from Ancient Greek ῥόδον (rhódon, “rose”) (Aeoli...

ROSY.e: From Middle English rosy; equivalent to rose + -y.

ROTA.d: A schedule that allocates some task, responsibility or (rarely) privilege between a set of people according to a (possibly periodic) calendar.
ROTA.e: Borrowed from Latin rota (“wheel”). Doublet of rotor and ruote.

ROTE.d: Mechanical routine; a fixed, habitual, repetitive, or mechanical course of procedure.
ROTE.e: From Middle English rote (“custom, habit, wont, condition, state”), further origin unknown. Found in the Middle English phrase bi rote (“by heart, according to form, expertly”), c. 1300. Some have proposed a relationship either with Old French rote/rute (“route”), or Latin rota (...

ROTS.d: Plural of ROT: To suffer decomposition due to biological action, especially by fungi or bacteria.
ROTS.e: Inherited from Middle English roten, rotten, from Old English rotian (“to rot, become corrupted, ulcerate, putrefy”), from Proto-West Germanic *rotēn, from Proto-Germanic *rutāną (“to rot”).

ROUT.d: A group of people; a crowd, a throng, a troop; in particular (archaic), a group of people accompanying or travelling with someone.
